verbs.description: tromp (third-person singular simple present tromps, present participle tromping, simple past and past participle tromped)

entries.meaning: (chiefly US, transitive, intransitive) To tread heavily, especially to crush underfoot.
examples: Synonyms: march, stamp, stomp, tramp, trample
Mother yelled at my brothers for tromping through her flowerbed.
The hoodlums were tromping pumpkins they had stolen from their neighbors' Halloween displays.
Synonyms: clobber, decimate, rout, trounce, whip
The team had been tromped by their cross-town rivals, and the players were embarrassed to show their faces in school the next day.

description: French trombe, trompe, a waterspout, a water-blowing machine. Compare trump, a trumpet.

entries.meaning: A blowing apparatus in which air, drawn into the upper part of a vertical tube through side holes by a stream of water within, is carried down with the water into a box or chamber below which it is led to a furnace.
